heading: 1 About
text: sample book written Markdown. can use anything Pandoc’s Markdown supports; example, math equation \(^2 + b^2 = c^2\).

heading: 1.1 Usage
text: bookdown chapter .Rmd file, .Rmd file can contain one (one) chapter. chapter must start first-level heading: # good chapter, can contain one (one) first-level heading.Use second-level higher headings within chapters like: ## short section ### even shorter section.index.Rmd file required, also first book chapter. homepage render book.

heading: 1.2 Render book
text: can render HTML version example book without changing anything:Find Build pane RStudio IDE, andFind Build pane RStudio IDE, andClick Build Book, select output format, select “formats” ’d like use multiple formats book source files.Click Build Book, select output format, select “formats” ’d like use multiple formats book source files.build book R console:render example PDF bookdown::pdf_book, ’ll need install XeLaTeX. recommended install TinyTeX (includes XeLaTeX): https://yihui.org/tinytex/.

heading: 1.3 Preview book
text: work, may start local server live preview HTML book. preview update edit book save individual .Rmd files. can start server work session using RStudio add-“Preview book”, R console:

heading: 2 About bookdown
text: chapters start first-level heading followed chapter title, like line . one first-level heading (#) per .Rmd file.

heading: 2.1 A section
text: chapter sections start second-level (##) higher heading followed section title, like sections . can many want within chapter.

heading: An unnumbered section
text: Chapters sections numbered default. un-number heading, add {.unnumbered} shorter {-} end heading, like section.

heading: 4.1 The book
text:
Spatial Temporal Methods Environmental Epidemiology R , like first Edition, explores interface environmental epidemiology spatio-temporal modelling. links recent developments spatio-temporal theory epidemiological applications. Drawing real-life problems, shows recent advances methodology, can assess health risks associated environmental hazards. book’s clear guidelines enable implementation methodology estimation risks practice.text covers wide range topics epidemiological principles foundations spatio-temporal modelling. New current research directions explored. Traditional Bayesian approaches presented. Practical examples demonstrate listed computer code information may gleaned data uncertainty reduced. Supplementary material presented R Bookdown, located GitHub site. , reader find amongst things: additional code; data; examples;, exercises; lab projects.Features
1. Explores interface environmental epidemiology spatio¬ temporal modelling
Incorporates examples show spatio-temporal methodology can inform societal concerns effects environmental hazards health
2. Uses Bayesian foundation build integrated approach spatio-temporal modelling environmental epidemiology
3. Discusses data analysis topics data visualization, mapping, wrangling analysis
4. Shows design networks monitoring hazardous environmental processes networks ill-effects preferential sampling
5. listing application code, shows power R, tidyverse, NIMBLE Stan modern tools can provide information reduces uncertainty.Representing major direction environmental epidemiology, book-full color throughout – underscores increasing need consider dependencies space time modelling epidemiological data. Readers learn identify model patterns spatio-temporal data well exploit dependencies space time reduce bias inefficiency.

heading: 4.2 The supplementary material
text: R Bookdown supplement contains following material.

heading: 4.2.1 A set of course projects for assignment with solutions
4.2.2 Four labs assignments for students in a course based on the book
4.2.3 Lecture notes for a full graduate level course to accompany the book
5 Cross-references
text: Cross-references make easier readers find link elements book.

heading: 5.1 Chapters and sub-chapters
text:
two steps cross-reference heading:Label heading: # Hello world {#nice-label}.
Leave label like automated heading generated based heading title: example, # Hello world = # Hello world {#hello-world}.
label un-numbered heading, use: # Hello world {-#nice-label} {# Hello world .unnumbered}.
Leave label like automated heading generated based heading title: example, # Hello world = # Hello world {#hello-world}.label un-numbered heading, use: # Hello world {-#nice-label} {# Hello world .unnumbered}.Next, reference labeled heading anywhere text using \@ref(nice-label); example, please see Chapter 5.
prefer text link instead numbered reference use: text want can go .
prefer text link instead numbered reference use: text want can go .

heading: 5.2 Captioned figures and tables
text:
Figures tables captions can also cross-referenced elsewhere book using \@ref(fig:chunk-label) \@ref(tab:chunk-label), respectively.See Figure 5.1.
Figure 5.1: nice figure!
Don’t miss Table 5.1.Table 5.1: nice table!
code:
par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1))
plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19)
knitr::kable(
  head(pressure, 10), caption = 'Here is a nice table!',
  booktabs = TRUE
)

Chapters appendix prepended letters instead numbers.

text:
Reference items bibliography file(s) using @key.example, using bookdown package2 (check last code chunk index.Rmd see citation key added) sample book, built top R Markdown knitr3 (citation added manually external file book.bib).
Note .bib files need listed index.Rmd YAML bibliography key.bs4_book theme makes footnotes appear inline click . example book, added csl: chicago-fullnote-bibliography.csl index.Rmd YAML, include .csl file. download new style, recommend: https://www.zotero.org/styles/RStudio Visual Markdown Editor can also make easier insert citations: https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/#/citations

&=&

\beta\_{}
